Award.AwardTitle: Two-component Winds from Eye-safe Elastic LIDAR and Optical Flow above the Reach of Most Towers
Award.AbstractNarration: Improved observations of the detailed spatial structure of low-level airflow over areas on the order of ten square kilometers or more and for extended time periods are needed to advance research in the atmospheric sciences and related applications. This project will develop and evaluate the ability of a ground-based, scanning, eye-safe elastic backscatter LIDAR (LIght Detection And Ranging) observing system coupled with two candidate numerical motion estimation algorithms to determine vector wind fields above the reach of typical portable meteorological towers (i.e., heights of 50-150 m AGL) in the optically-clear atmosphere and over periods of several months. The project will utilize an NSF-developed asset, the transportable Raman-shifted Eye-safe Aerosol Lidar (REAL), as the elastic backscatter lidar. The two numerical wind retrieval techniques that will ingest image-type lidar data are an existing "cross-correlation" method as well as a wavelet-based "optical flow" approach. The latter has been recently developed by French collaborators. Both techniques will be implemented via software optimized to take advantage of the massively parallel yet compact, energy efficient, and affordable power of graphical processing units. This will result in a significant enhancement of the elastic lidar system by enabling it to produce wind-field observations in real-time. Both modes of airflow estimation will be compared with independent wind measurements from a small, eye-safe Doppler lidar operating at the same infrared wavelength as the elastic lidar. The Intellectual Merit of this project centers on the development and evaluation of improved and reliable means for retrieving the structure and evolution of small-scale boundary layer flow features. Broader Impacts of this effort will include strengthened collaborations for critical characterization of the resulting flow fields and use of the flow fields to advance understanding of boundary layer processes (e.g., airflow in stable nocturnal boundary layers) as well as enhanced undergraduate education involving students drawn from a wide variety of majors, who will be assigned to tightly-focused tasks in support of this project's stated goals. Hands-on training for a graduate-student and mentorship of a post-doctoral research associate will be provided to ensure successful outcomes. Results will be disseminated via peer-reviewed literature and a combination of domestic and international conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wind and turbulence in the lowest one hundred meters of the atmosphere is very important for a number of reasons.   In terms of human enterprises, consider the great impact of the wind on the dispersion of pollutants, airport safety, wind energy, and wildfire suppression.  In addition to these, the wind and turbulence near the surface of the Earth control the vertical flux of heat (temperature), momentum (i.e., velocity), and naturally occurring trace gases such as water vapor and carbon dioxide.  Therefore, wind and turbulence play a critical role in climate, and it must be correctly parameterized for successful weather and climate predictions.

Yet, when it comes to our ability to observe the wind, relatively few technologies are at our disposal.   The most popular way is through the use of anemometers attached towers.   Small Doppler lidars excel at measuring vertical profiles of horizontal wind vectors.  But, the ability to visualize the wind field over large areas (e.g., the size of neighborhoods) remains a challenge.  The primary objective of this project has been to develop and validate a remote wind field measurement technique that uses a scanning elastic backscatter aerosol lidars and motion estimation algorithms.   The approach is one that is similar to particle image velocimetry (PIV) that is widely practiced by fluid engineers in controlled laboratory experiments. 

During years 1 – 3, this project developed a wavelet-based optical flow motion estimation algorithm (named Typhoon).   Pierre Dérian originally developed the algorithm at INRIA in France for his doctoral research.  Under this NSF funding, Dr. Dérian worked in Chico, California as a post-doctoral researcher with the California State University Chico Atmospheric Lidar Group to adapt Typhoon so that it could be successfully applied to data produced by the Raman-shifted Eye-safe Aerosol Lidar (REAL).  The team also performed extensive testing of the approach by conducting a field experiment.   The results of that research were disseminated through peer reviewed journal articles and international conference presentations, as well as highlights published on the research group’s website: lidar.csuchico.edu.

In the 4th, no-cost extension year, two areas of research activity occurred.  First, results obtained during the first 3 years, including those from a March 2015 pilot experiment to test the feasibility of using the technique to measure the wind field over the ocean, were disseminated at a two conferences.   Second, data from a 2007 field experiment (the Canopy Horizontal Array Turbulence Study or CHATS) was further analyzed and a journal manuscript was drafted.   The results of the pilot experiment successfully demonstrated the feasibility of using this technique to measure wind over breaking ocean waves.  The analysis of data from the 2007 experiment provide new insights on the physical characteristics of fine-scale atmospheric waves that often occur during the night over vegetated land and sometimes break leading to episodes of turbulence.
